Vision system from ANJI (my own implement=
ation of it).. current 
results show that with HyperNEAT it learns actually=
 better, and the 
circular substrate configuration increases performance am=
ong 
others. :)

> Assigning node-centric values is a legitimate research p=
roblem.  
The 
> simplest answer is that a CPPN can have more than a single=
 output.  
> There can be additional outputs for things like biases and lea=
rning 
> rates.  Each such property will then be patterned across the 
subs=
trate 
> just like weights.
> 
> However, the one problem that comes up wit=
h nodes is that node-
centric 
> properties are overspecified by a 4D CPPN =
because nodes are 
specified 
> by only two dimensions (that is, they are p=
oints in space rather 
than 
> lines).  Therefore, you have to set a conven=
tion for when to read 
the 
> value of a node-centric output and assign it =
to a node.  For 
example, 
> you could say that the node at x1 y1 is set to=
 the value of the 
node 
> output only when x2 y2 are both zero.  Of course=
 there are many 
> alternative ways it could be done, but some convention m=
ust be 
set.  

I will try to do the following.. the CPPN will have 2 more =
outputs, 
that will specity the time constant and bias of THE SECOND node, =

(x2,y2) .. I think this shouldn't hurt performance.. But I guess it 
will =
take some trial and error.
